lead_paragraph: One principle I like to emphasize is that in times of radical change and stress, analytical economics is more rather than less useful than usual. (Or it is if the economist doing it is really trying to make sense of events rather than fitting everything into his ideological preconceptions.) Why? Because in unusual and stressful situations, experience -- the kind of experience business people gather over years in the market --ceases to be a helpful guide, whereas models and deep historical knowledge have at least a hope of getting at what's really going on.
